question_category.name: Default for OER_1
question_category.info: The default category for questions shared in context 'OER_1'.

question.name: Public Domain Logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

answer.feedback: Yes correct!

question_category.name: C1-Mod_1
question_category.info: Questions related to Module one in Course 1 OER STEM.

question.name: Course shell - purpose
question.questiontext: What is the stated purpose of the course shell"Build a Lesson with OER?"

answer.answertext: The course shell provides resources, presentations and materials to help you build your own OER online learning object for your learners using the learning management system Moodle.
answer.feedback: Yes, it is a starting point to create your own learning activity or course using OER.
That's OK, you will learn more about the courselet if you continue your studies in the OER math or OER science courses.

answer.answertext: It is a Moodle course I can use to help my students learn.
answer.feedback: This is true, but not the entire purpose, you still earn half credit. Review Unit 1.

question.name: Course Outcomes -matching
question.questiontext: Match the stated course outcomes from Unit 1 below.

match.questiontext: You will gain a foundational understanding of Open Educational Resources (OER) and how they can enrich your teaching.
You will gain search skills to refine search queries, apply appropriate filters, and determine licensing requirements.
You will learn how to use OER Commons, a repository of educational resources, to find, review, evaluate and save your favorite OER materials
You will learn how to create an OER.
match.answertext: This was not a stated outcome.

question_category.name: C1-Mod_2
question_category.info: Questions related to Module two in Course 1 OER STEM.

question.name: 5rs - David Wiley
question.questiontext: The key to understanding OER lies in the phrase "resources that reside in the public domain or have been released under an intellectual property license that permits their free use and re-purposing by others." David Wiley refined this concept through the "5Rs Framework." Choose the statement below that represents Mr. Wiley's 5Rs Framework.

answer.feedback: Yes! That is correct.

That is not entirely correct. This answer represents only 4 items in the framework. You still get half credit because these were the ORIGINAL elements of the framework before being revised by Mr. Wiley.
That is not correct. Review Unit  2.
That's OK! As you go through the course you will learn more -- especially in Unit 2.

question.name: Types of OER
question.questiontext: Choose which items that can be considered an Open Educational Resource.

answer.answertext: Digital documents like lesson plans or textbooks.
answer.feedback: Yes, documents can be downloaded and printed for local use, or read online.

answer.answertext: Digital media like video lectures, screencasts, video tutorials, audio files and music.
answer.feedback: Yes, media can be licensed as an OER.
Correct, these types of resources can be licensed as an OER.

answer.answertext: Online courses in a variety of subjects, they can be teacher created or from institutions like MIT.
answer.feedback: You are right!

question.name: CC BY logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

answer.feedback: Not quite; this license also indicates BY, for attribution, as well. (Partial credit given.)
That's OK, you'll learn more about these types of licenses in Module 2.

question.name: Define OER acyronm
question.questiontext: What do the letters O E R stand for?

question.name: Definition OER - NETP
question.questiontext: The definition for Open Educational Resources (OER) cites specific resources that reside in the public domain or have been released under an intellectual property license that permits sharing, accessing, repurposing--including for commercial purposes--and collaborating with others. What are the resources specifically mentioned?

answer.feedback: Yes, these are specific types of resources mentioned within the definition in the National Educational Technology Plan (p. 56)

answer.answertext: data sites, educational research and multimedia resources

question.name: Understanding OER
question.questiontext: The key to understanding OER lies in the phrase "resources that reside in the _________________ or have been released under an intellectual property license that permits their free use and re-purposing by others."

answer.feedback: Yes, you are correct.
That's OK, you'll learn more about licensing in Module 2.

question.name: Retain 5Rs
question.questiontext: From the list of words below, which means "the right to make, own, and control copies of the content (e.g. download, duplicate, store, and manage) in the 5R's Framework?"

answer.feedback: That's OK, you'll learn more about these terms in Module 2.

question.name: Reuse 5Rs
question.questiontext: From the list of words below, which means "the right to use the content in a wide range of ways (e.g. in a class, in a study group, on a website, in a video)" as part of the 5R's Framework?

answer.feedback: Yes, you are correct.
That's OK, you'll learn more about the 5R's Framework in Module 2.

question.name: Revise - 5Rs
question.questiontext: From the list of words below, which means "the right to adapt, adjust, modify, or alter the content itself (e.g., translate the content into another language)" as part of the 5R's Framework?

answer.feedback: Yes, you are correct.
That's OK, you'll learn more about the 5R's Framework in Module 2.

question.name: Remix 5Rs
question.questiontext: From the list of words below, which means "the right to combine the original or revised content with other open content to create something new (e.g. incorporate the content into a mash-up)" as part of the 5R's Framework?

answer.feedback: Yes, you are correct.
That's OK, you'll learn more about licensing in Module 2.

question.name: Redistribute 5Rs
question.questiontext: From the list of words below, which term means "the right to share copies of the original content, your revisions, or your remixes with others (e.g., give a copy of the content to a friend)" as part of the 5R's Framework?

answer.feedback: Yes, you are correct.

question.name: Define open - 5R activities
question.questiontext:
When a resource is licensed in a way that allows users to engage in the 5R activities, the content is considered to be licensed as which of the following?

Content is considered _________ to the extent that its license allows users to engage in the 5R activities.

answer.feedback: Be careful not to confuse "free to use" versus an "open" resource. Materials can be free, but they are still copyright protected by the owner, and you typically cannot modify them.

question.name: Less open license - 5R
question.questiontext: On a scale of "less open" and "more open" if a license places restrictions or requirements on a users ability to engage in the 5R activities, which of these options would apply to the work?

answer.feedback: You are correct, any license that places restrictions on how a work can be used would be considered "less open."
That's OK, you'll learn more about the 5R's and licensing in Unit 2.

question.name: Tech advances
question.questiontext: Advances in _______________ make it possible to share information and resources through the Internet.

question.name: Online resources protected by
question.questiontext: You should assume that most resources we find online are protected by a  __________ license.

answer.feedback: That's OK, you'll learn more about licenses in Module 2.

question.name: Check the license
question.questiontext: Select the best answer from the list below regarding how you should approach using materials you find on the Internet.

answer.answertext: As an educator, you should always check the license on any materials you want to use.
answer.feedback: Yes, never assume that because you found it online you can use it any way you want.

answer.answertext: As an educator, there is no need to check the license on any materials you want to use.
Checking the license of works found online is not necessary.

answer.feedback: That's OK, you'll learn more about licensing in Module 2, and how to search for appropriately licensed materials in Unit 3.

question.name: Assume copyright protected
question.questiontext: Which of the following statements is most accurate when you are considering using resources you found on the Internet?

answer.feedback: Be careful about this assumption. It is best to assume that all materials found on the Internet are protected by Copyright. Always check the licensing to determine how you can use the material.
That's OK, you'll learn more about this in module 2.

question.name: Where to find rights
question.questiontext: When trying to determine the usage rights of a specific resources, which section of the website should you check?

answer.feedback: This is partially correct, there are more areas you could check too.
This is partially correct, there are more areas you could check too.
This is partially correct, there are more areas you could check too.
Yes, this is correct. You may have to check more than one area to find the usage rights on a website.

question.name: If you don't know -what should you do?
question.questiontext: If you are unable to find information about a resource's usage rights on a website, what should you do?

answer.feedback: This is a good alternative, but if the resource is really good you should always ask.

answer.answertext: ask for information by using the site's "contact us" or "help" link

answer.feedback: That's OK, you'll learn more about licensing in module 2 and searching in module 3.

question.name: Abbreviation CC
question.questiontext: What does the abbreviation CC stand for?

question.name: Marked as free cultural work
question.questiontext: If a resource is marked as 'Approved for Free Cultural Works,' what does that mean?

answer.answertext: It is one of the more open licenses.
answer.feedback: Yes you are correct! Read more about Free Cultural Works here: Https://creativecommons.org/freeworks

answer.answertext: It is one of the less open licenses.

answer.feedback: That's OK, you'll learn more about licensing in Unit 2.

question.name: Which is more open
question.questiontext: Which of these licenses is more open?

answer.answertext: CC BY
answer.feedback: You are correct, the CC-BY (Creative Commons Attribution) is the most open license requiring only attribution to the original creator.

answer.answertext: CC BY NC ND
answer.feedback: This license is considered less open because it restricts users from commercial use, and does not allow for any derivative works.
That's OK, you'll learn more about licensing in Unit 2.

question.name: Which is more Open 2
question.questiontext: Which of these licenses is more open?

answer.answertext: Creative Commons Attribution No-Derivs
answer.feedback: This license does not permit any derivative works, so it is less open than some of the other Creative Commons licenses.

answer.answertext: Public Domain
answer.feedback: You are correct. Public domain is the purest form of open/free, since no one owns or controls the material in any way. (See https://wiki.creativesommons.org/Public_domain)

question.name: Where can you share your work
question.questiontext: Where can you share your work?

question.name: Less open 2
question.questiontext: Which license is less open?

answer.answertext: CC BY SA
answer.feedback: A license with attribution (BY) and share-alike (SA) is considered an open license.

answer.answertext: CC BY NC ND
answer.feedback: You are correct. This license does not permit commercial use or any derivative works, so it is less open than some of the other Creative Commons licenses.
That's OK, you'll learn more about these types of licenses in Unit 2.

question.name: Less open 3
question.questiontext: Which license is less open?

answer.answertext: CC BY SA
answer.feedback: You are correct. This license does not permit commercial use, so it is less open than some of the other Creative Commons licenses.

answer.answertext: CC BY
answer.feedback: CC-BY is an open license only requiring attribution (BY) to the creator.
That's OK, you'll learn more about licenses in Unit 2.

question.name: Attribution (Bonus question)
question.questiontext: When you use an OER in your work, what elements should you include in the attribution? Select the best answer from the list below.
question.generalfeedback: Review Creative Commons and the "Best practices for attribution" websites. TASL is an acronym that can help you remember: Title, Author, Source, License.

answer.answertext: title of the resource, authors name, source, and license.
answer.feedback: That is correct! Think TASL!
Not quite, think TASL: Title, Author, Source and License.
Not quite, think TASL: Title, Author, Source and License.
Not quite, think TASL: Title, Author, Source and License.

question.name: CC BY SA logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

question.name: CC BY ND Logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

question.name: CC BY NC Logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

question.name: CC BY NC ND Logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

question.name: CC BY NC SA Logo
question.questiontext: This image represents a certain Creative Commons License. Choose the correct answer from the list below.

question.name: Match the license
question.questiontext: Match the license icon to the correct definition.

match.answertext: This license lets other distribute, remix, tweak, and build upon your work, even commercially, as long as they credit you for the original creation.

This license lets others remix, tweak, and build upon your work non-commercially, and although their new works must also acknowldge you and be non-commercial, they don't have to license their derivative works on the same terms.
This work is free for use by anyone for any purpose without restriction under copyright law. This is the purest form of open/free.

question_category.name: C1-Mod_3
question_category.info: Questions related to Module three in Course 1 OER STEM.

question.name: 5Rs and open content
question.questiontext: Which Framework expresses the primary permission (or usage rights) for open content?

question.name: Open pedagogy - practice is
question.questiontext: Open ___________________ is a practice of openness in learning and teaching that shares all phases and elements of instruction.

question.name: When you share...
question.questiontext: When you share materials that you have created, you deserve to:

answer.answertext: license it so you receive credit for the excellent work you produce
answer.feedback: You should always receive credit for your creations. (You earned one point for this answer.)

answer.answertext: ensure the material is used in a way you deem most appropriate
answer.feedback: By licensing it, you know how your work will be used in the future. (You earned one point for this answer.)

answer.answertext: be recognized as a contributor to educators everywhere far beyond your local classroom
answer.feedback: Sharing your work allows you to expand into larger educational networks. (You earned one point for this answer.)
Yes, all of these answers are correct. If you only choose this answer, you've earned one point.

question.name: Repository - define
question.questiontext: What do you call a website that curates and stores a collection of online resources?

answer.feedback: This is a reasonable answer, but a library curates books more than websites.
That's OK, you'll learn more about these types of websites in Unit 3.

question.name: steps for effective searching
question.questiontext: Select the best answer that represents the process of an effective search.

answer.answertext: Define your search question, identify key words, write effective search terms, and use advanced features to refine and improve your search results.
answer.feedback: Yes, this is the best answer because it encompasses all the steps to create and refine your search for OER.

answer.answertext: Write key terms in the search box, review all the search results.
answer.feedback: This answer doesn't encompass the other elements of a good search strategy.

answer.answertext: Type in key terms in the search box, refine the results with advanced search features.
answer.feedback: It is important to define your question and key terms first.

answer.answertext: Use advanced search tools to refine your search query.
answer.feedback: This answer doesn't encompass the other elements of a good search strategy.

question.name: Repository - classify resources
question.questiontext: Repositories can classify resources by which of the following categories? Choose all that apply from the list below.

question.name: OER Commons - added AE
question.questiontext: Of the websites listed below, which one provides an "adult education" filter to its grade level category?

answer.feedback: Yes, OER Commons allows users to filter results for adult learners.
That's OK, you'll learn more about searching and using filters in Unit 3.

question.name: OER Portfolio *review
question.questiontext: Which link on the OER Commons web site allows you to see your saved, evaluated, remixed and authored items?

answer.feedback: Yes, this is correct. You can see all your saved, submitted, remixed and authored items by selecting "My OER" from the OER Commons home page after you have logged in.
That's OK, you'll learn more about OER Commons in Module 3.

question.name: OER Commons - My OER
question.questiontext: On the OER Commons site, what button should you click in order to go to My Profile, My Items and My Groups?

answer.feedback: That's OK, you'll learn more about OER Commons in Unit  3.

question.name: OER Commons - what can you do
question.questiontext: The OER Commons website allows you to do many things related to Open Educational Resources. Select all the activities you can do from the list below.

answer.feedback: This is not something you can do on the OER Commons website.
